raw_text:
IMF agrees fresh Turkey funding
 
 Turkey has agreed a draft proposal with the International Monetary Fund to borrow $10bn (£5.19bn), extending its ongoing financial support until 2007.
 
 Turkey's current $18.6bn loan agreement with the IMF expires in February and the new deal would see it receive added support between 2005 and 2007. In return for the funding, Turkey would be expected to keep inflation under control and introduce market reforms. Turkey's economy has steadily recovered from a severe crisis in 2001.
 
 Economic growth has average 6-7% in the past three years, ahead of IMF forecasts, while inflation fell below 10% this year for the first time in 30 years. However, Turkey has a huge debt burden - already owing $23bn to the IMF - while its current account deficit has swelled to $10.7bn this year.
 
 The Turkish economics minister, Ali Babacan, said the two sides had reached general agreement on a new three year funding program. Rodrigo de Rato, the IMF's managing director, said the loan agreement would help to improve Turkish economic prospects by cutting its debt and stimulating growth. "I believe the new programme, if implemented successfully, will help Turkey create the conditions for sustained growth and employment creation, reduce inflation toward European level and enhance the economy's resilience," he said. The agreement must still be ratified by IMF directors at a meeting expected to take place next month.
 
 The agreement would also enable Turkey to defer payments on previous loans worth $3.7m until 2006.
 
 As part of the draft agreement, Turkey has signed a "letter of intent" stating its determination to push through far-reaching reforms to its tax and benefits system and its banking sector. Such reforms are considered vital for Turkey if it is to fulfil its ambition of joining the European Union. The EU will decide on 17 December whether to begin entry talks with Turkey. The US, the largest of the IMF's 184 members, is a strong supporter of continued financial support for Turkey.
llama3.2:1b: Turkey has agreed a draft proposal with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to borrow $10bn and extend its loan agreement until 2007 in exchange for inflation control and market reforms. The loan would be part of a three-year funding program, which includes improving Turkish economic prospects by cutting debt and stimulating growth.
llama3.2:3b: Turkey agrees to $10bn IMF loan extension until 2007, replacing current $18.6bn deal, in exchange for inflation control and market reforms. The new funding will help reduce debt and stimulate growth, with the goal of creating conditions for sustained growth, employment creation, and reduced inflation toward European levels.
gemma2:2b: Turkey has reached an agreement with the IMF to receive $10 billion in funding until 2007. The deal includes conditions like controlling inflation and implementing market reforms.  The loan will help Turkey reduce its debt burden, stimulate economic growth, and prepare for potential EU membership.  IMF Managing Director Rodrigo de Rato believes this agreement will contribute to sustained economic stability and create employment opportunities.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key points:

- Turkey agreed to extend its $10bn loan agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) until 2007.
- The deal includes an additional $5.19bn in ongoing financial support between 2005 and 2007.
- Turkey would be expected to keep inflation under control, introduce market reforms, and address economic growth issues like a severe crisis in 2001.
- Turkey's economy has been steadily recovering from the 2001 crisis.
- The IMF expects Turkey's GDP average 6-7% over the next three years, ahead of its forecasted growth rate.
- Turkey is currently owed $23bn to the IMF and currently accounts for $10.7bn in annual payments.
- The Turkish economy is expected to average around 6-7% growth, but inflation has fallen below 10% this year.
- The agreement would help improve Turkey's economic prospects by cutting its debt and stimulating growth.
- Turkey signed a "letter of intent" stating its determination to push through far-reaching reforms to its tax and benefits system and banking sector.
- The deal includes deferred payments on previous loans worth $3.7m until 2006.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The International Monetary Fund has agreed a $10 billion loan deal with Turkey extending its ongoing financial assistance until 2007, conditional on economic reforms and inflation control. The move aims to bolster Turkey's economy from the $23 billion IMF debt and reduce current account deficits. The agreement must still be ratified by IMF directors before implementation.
qwen2.5:3b: Turkey has agreed a draft proposal with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to borrow $10bn until 2007, extending its current $18.6bn loan agreement expiring in February. This new deal aims to provide added support between 2005 and 2007, contingent on Turkey controlling inflation and implementing market reforms despite its large debt burden ($23bn owed to IMF) and increasing current account deficit ($10.7bn). Economic growth has been steady at 6-7% over the past three years, below IMF forecasts but with inflation falling to under 10%, a 30-year low. Turkish economics minister Ali Babacan and IMF's managing director Rodrigo de Rato both supported the agreement, which must be ratified by IMF directors in coming months. The deal includes deferred payments on previous loans ($3.7m) until 2006. In return, Turkey is expected to push through far-reaching reforms in its tax/benefits system and banking sector. The EU will decide on 17 December whether to begin entry talks with Turkey, with US support for continued financial aid strong.
opencoder:1.5b:
IMF agrees fresh Turkey funding

Turkey has agreed a draft proposal with the International Monetary Fund to borrow $10bn (£5.19bn), extending its ongoing financial support until 2007.

Turkey's current $18.6bn loan agreement with the IMF expires in February and the new deal would see it receive added support between 2005 and 2007. In return for the funding, Turkey would be expected to keep inflation under control and introduce market reforms.

Turkey's economy has steadily recovered from a severe crisis in 2001.

Economic growth has average 6-7% in the past three years, ahead of IMF forecasts, while inflation fell below 10% this year for the first time in 30 years. However, Turkey has a huge debt burden - already owing $23bn to the IMF - while its current account deficit has swelled to $10.7bn this year.

The Turkish economics minister, Ali Babacan, said the two sides had reached general agreement on a new three year funding program. Rodrigo de Rato, the IMF's managing director, said the loan agreement would help to improve Turkish economic prospects by cutting its debt and stimulating growth. "I believe the new programme, if implemented successfully, will help Turkey create the conditions for sustained growth and employment creation, reduce inflation toward European level and enhance the economy's resilience," he said.

The agreement must still be ratified by IMF directors at a meeting expected to take place next month. 

Turkey has signed a "letter of intent" stating its determination to push through far-reaching reforms to its tax and benefits system and its banking sector. Such reforms are considered vital for Turkey if it is to fulfil its ambition of joining the European Union. The EU will decide on 17 December whether to begin entry talks with Turkey. The US, the largest of the IMF's 184 members, is a strong supporter of continued financial support for Turkey.
smollm:1.7b: The IMF agrees fresh funding with Turkey to extend its ongoing financial support until 2007. In return, Turkey would be expected to keep inflation under control and introduce market reforms. The IMF has already agreed on a new three year funding program that will help Turkey create the conditions for sustained growth and employment creation.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about the Turkish government agreeing with the IMF to get more funding. Let me read through it again and pick out the key points.

First, I see that Turkey has agreed to borrow $10 billion from the IMF. They have a current agreement with the IMF that expires in February, so they're planning to receive additional support between 2005 and 2007. They get this money in return for keeping inflation under control and introducing market reforms. 

Turkey's economy has been recovering well since 2001, growing steadily at around 6-7% over the past three years. But the current account deficit is up to $10.7 billion this year, which is a significant issue. They also have a massive debt burden of $23 billion against the IMF.

The Turkish economics minister, Ali Babacan, says they've reached agreement on a new funding program proposed by Rodrigo de Rato, the IMF's manager. This new loan will help improve Turkey's economic prospects by reducing debt and boosting growth. He mentions that if the program works, it could create better conditions for sustained growth, employment, and reduce inflation to European levels.

There are other details too, like the agreement allows deferring previous loans until 2006, which might be a way for Turkey to avoid paying more money back on past debts by then. Also, they signed a letter of intent about reforms in taxes and benefits, banking sector, which are crucial if they want to join the EU.

The agreement's approval is expected at an upcoming IMF meeting on December 17. The US is supportive because the IMF is a big member there. Turkey aims to join the EU within that year. The draft proposal also mentions economic recovery from the 2001 crisis, with growth rates improving and inflation dropping to new lows.

I need to make sure I capture all these points without getting too detailed. Focus on the main agreement, the financial terms, the economic challenges, the reforms they're proposing, the funding details, and the upcoming approval date.
</think>

IMF agrees to provide Turkish $10 billion in financial support, extending its current $18.6 billion loan through a draft proposal due by 2007. Turkey aims to keep inflation low, reduce debt, and stimulate growth. Economic recovery from 2001 with average 6-7% growth over three years, though inflation fell to below 10%. Turkey has a $23 billion IMF debt burden and a current account deficit of $10.7 billion this year. They signed reforms in taxes, benefits, and banking sectors, crucial for EU entry on December 17 when the draft agreement is expected to be approved.
tinyllama:1.1b: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has agreed on a new three-year funding program for Turkey, aimed at reducing its debt burden and stimulating growth while improving the economy's prospects. The agreement will also allow Turkey to pay off previous loans worth $3.7m by 2006, and the IMF has expressed its determination to push through far-reaching reform packages aimed at modernizing the country's tax and benefits system and its banking sector. While Turkey's economic growth averaged 6-7% over the past three years, inflation fell below 10% this year for the first time in 30 years, and the country has a huge debt burden - already owed $23bn to the IMF - while its current account deficiit has swollen to $10.7bn this year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Turkey and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) have agreed on a fresh funding proposal worth $10bn to extend their existing loan agreement until February 2007, according to Turkish Economics Minister Ali Babacan. The new deal would see Turkey's current $18.6bn loan with the IMF extended for another three years, starting in 2005 and ending in February 2007. In return for the funding, Turkey will implement market-reform measures, including an overhaul of its tax and benefits systems, as well as a review of its banking sector. This decision is seen as essential for Turkey if it is to join the European Union. The IMF's managing director, Rodrigo de Rato, believes that this funding will help improve Turkish economic prospects by reducing its debt burden and stimulating growth. However, he emphasizes that implementation of the new programme must be ratified by the IMF's directors at a meeting to take place next month.
phi:2.7b: In January 2006, Turkey agreed to borrow $10 billion from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to extend its ongoing financial support until 2007. The new loan would be used to maintain economic growth and bring down inflation, while the country's debt burden and current account deficit were high. The IMF will monitor the implementation of the program closely.
orca-mini:3b: The International Monetary Fund has agreed to provide $10 billion in fresh funding to Turkey until 2007, under the condition that Turkey maintains inflation under control and implements market reforms. The deal would enable Turkey to defer payments on previous loans worth $3.7 million until 2006. Turkey's economy has been steadily recovering from a severe crisis in 2001, with average economic growth of 6-7% over the past three years and inflation falling below 10%. However, Turkey still faces a large debt burden and a high current account deficit. The new loan agreement would help Turkey create conditions for sustained growth and employment creation, reduce inflation toward European level, and enhance the economy's resilience.
hermes3:3b: IMF agrees $10bn funding for Turkey until 2007, extending loan agreement until 2007 and requiring inflation control and market reforms.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Turkey has agreed to borrow $10 billion from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) until 2007, extending its ongoing financial support. As part of the deal, Turkey must keep inflation under control and introduce market reforms. Its economy has recovered since a severe crisis in 2001, with average growth of 6-7% over the past three years. However, it has a large debt burden and a current account deficit. The agreement must be ratified by IMF directors next month.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Turkey has agreed to a draft proposal with the IMF for a $10 billion loan, extending financial support until 2007. This follows its current $18.6 billion loan agreement, which expires in February. In return, Turkey must control inflation and implement market reforms. The economy has recovered since the 2001 crisis, with 6-7% growth and inflation below 10% for the first time in 30 years. However, Turkey faces a large debt burden and a growing current account deficit. Turkish Economics Minister Ali Babacan and IMF Managing Director Rodrigo de Rato believe the loan will reduce debt, boost growth, and enhance economic stability. The agreement, pending IMF board approval, allows Turkey to defer $3.7 million in loan payments until 2006. Turkey has committed to tax, benefits, and banking reforms, crucial for its EU membership ambitions, with the EU set to decide on entry talks on 17 December. The US strongly supports continued IMF aid to Turkey.
stablelm2:1.6b: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has agreed to provide $5.6 billion (£5 billion) in funding for Turkey, extending its ongoing assistance until 2017. The deal will see Turkey receive additional support between $5 and $7 billion over a three-year period, while keeping inflation under control and introducing market reforms. However, Turkey's economy has shown steady growth, with an average of 6-7% in the past three years, surpassing IMF forecasts. Inflation fell below 1% this year for the first time in 10 years. Despite these achievements, Turkey still owes $5 billion to the IMF and its current account deficit surged to $5.7 billion this year. The agreement requires approval by IMF directors at a meeting scheduled for December, with Turkey agreeing to significant reforms to its tax and benefits system and banking sector.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Turkey has secured an extended $10bn loan from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), pushing back its debt maturity until 2007. This new agreement, to be finalized in an IMF director meeting next month, aims to stabilize Turkey's economy, which has been recovering from a 2001 crisis with average annual growth of 6-7%. Despite this progress, Turkey faces significant challenges: it owes $23bn to the IMF and has a record current account deficit of $10.7bn due to high debt and inflation (below 10% for the first time in 30 years).

In return for the funding, Turkey must maintain low inflation, control its balance of payments, and implement far-reaching economic reforms. These reforms focus on improving tax and benefits systems and banking sector regulations—crucial steps for Turkey's potential EU membership, with entry talks scheduled for December 17. The US supports continued financial assistance for Turkey.
reference: However, Turkey has a huge debt burden - already owing $23bn to the IMF - while its current account deficit has swelled to $10.7bn this year.Turkey's current $18.6bn loan agreement with the IMF expires in February and the new deal would see it receive added support between 2005 and 2007.The agreement would also enable Turkey to defer payments on previous loans worth $3.7m until 2006.Turkey has agreed a draft proposal with the International Monetary Fund to borrow $10bn (£5.19bn), extending its ongoing financial support until 2007.As part of the draft agreement, Turkey has signed a "letter of intent" stating its determination to push through far-reaching reforms to its tax and benefits system and its banking sector.In return for the funding, Turkey would be expected to keep inflation under control and introduce market reforms.
